neighbors.name: Robert & Susan Shotto
neighbors.claims: Robert and Susan Shotto owned a residential property on Summit Point Road in Jefferson County before selling it in September 2024 ([Zillow](https://www.zillow.com/homedetails/7963-Summit-Point-Rd-Charles-Town-WV-25414/22560068_zpid/)). Robert Shotto has been identified as a healthcare professional who has presented on Crew Resource Management principles ([DTIC](https://www.scribd.com/document/131998533/A-560817)). No evidence could be found of the Shottos participating in local meetings or taking public positions on development issues prior to the sale of their property.
neighbors.influence_justification: Private sellers; no public roles found

approach_recommendations.engage: Direct engagement is likely unnecessary as the property has been sold and the individuals have left the location.

neighbors.name: William R. & Janice E. Curtis
neighbors.claims: William and Janice Curtis are listed as owners of a parcel in Jefferson County, West Virginia. Public records indicate a William R. Curtis died in 2004 and a Janice E. Curtis died in 2013, suggesting the property may be held in an estate or trust, though this could not be definitively linked to this specific parcel ([Curtis Family Society](https://www.curtis-curtiss.org/document_view.asp?id=253)). There are no recent public statements or documented civic roles for a living William or Janice Curtis in local affairs.
neighbors.influence_justification: Likely deceased or inactive; no public profile

approach_recommendations.engage: Verify current ownership status through tax records or site visit, as listed owners may be deceased. Approach with sensitivity to potential estate or heirship issues.

neighbors.name: Vera H. Reid
neighbors.claims: Vera H. Reid was a lifelong Jefferson County resident who passed away in August 2024 at the age of 99 ([Legacy.com](https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/name/vera-reid-obituary?id=55809922)). She was a longtime 4-H club leader and served on the Jefferson County 4-H Foundation’s Board of Directors, reflecting deep community roots ([Legacy.com](https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/name/vera-reid-obituary?id=55809922)). She was also a member of the Charles Town Presbyterian Church and a singing quartet known as The Melodeers ([Legacy.com](https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/name/vera-reid-obituary?id=55809922)).
neighbors.influence_justification: Longtime community matriarch; 4-H Board Member

approach_recommendations.engage: Coordinate with the estate representatives, honoring the family’s legacy in the community and showing respect for the longstanding ties of the property.

citations.claim: Passed away in August 2024 at age 99
citations.title: Vera Hammersla Reid Obituary

citations.claim: Served on Jefferson County 4-H Foundation Board
citations.title: Vera Hammersla Reid Obituary

neighbors.name: Bonnie L. McDonald & Carroll E. Harder
neighbors.claims: Bonnie McDonald and Carroll Harder are listed as joint owners of a residential lot in Jefferson County. Genealogical records indicate a Carroll Edison Harder of Jefferson County died in 1971, suggesting the deed may reflect an estate or life estate status ([RootsWeb](http://sites.rootsweb.com/~viands/descendants_of_thomas_jefferson.htm)). Bonnie McDonald has not been publicly involved in recent county committees or land use debates according to available records.
neighbors.influence_justification: No public involvement; one owner likely deceased

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage the household with the understanding that ownership records may be outdated or held in trust. Focus on informal, friendly outreach to determine the current decision-maker.

neighbors.name: Stephen T. & Judith R. Smoot
neighbors.claims: Stephen Smoot is the Editor of the Moorefield Examiner and the Pendleton Times, where he actively covers local news and writes opinion pieces ([Moorefield Examiner](https://moorefieldexaminer.com/contact/)). In May 2024, he authored an article titled 'Profiles in Courage: Jefferson County Edition,' which defended local commissioners who took a stand during the heated controversy over solar farm construction in Jefferson County ([Shinnston News](https://shinnstonnews.com/profiles-in-courage-jefferson-county-edition/)). He has also reported on solar development projects in Hardy County, detailing community concerns and developer plans ([Moorefield Examiner](https://moorefieldexaminer.com/2025/10/21/open-house-shares-details-of-solar-farm-plan-in-old-fields/)).
neighbors.influence_justification: Newspaper Editor; writes on development policy

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach with high awareness of his role as a journalist and opinion shaper. He is knowledgeable about solar controversies. Engagement should be transparent, factual, and prepared for public scrutiny.

citations.title: Moorefield Examiner Staff Directory

Newman Jr. appears in regional records, including a 1972 graduate in Charleston, WV ([Pike Archive](http://www.pikearchive.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/11/PKA_SD_2003_AUTUMN.pdf)), specific details linking him to this Jefferson County parcel or military service could not be verified. neighbors.name: Donald K. Mickey & Gail H. Mickey
neighbors.claims: Donald K. Mickey and Gail H. Mickey are local landowners. Donald K. Mickey served Jefferson County schools for 30 years, notably as coordinator of guidance and testing ([Spirit of Jefferson](https://sjf.stparchive.com/Archive/SJF/SJF10261967P01.php)). In recognition of his service, the county designated June 23, 1989, as "Donald K. Mickey Day" ([Spirit of Jefferson](https://sjf.stparchive.com/Archive/SJF/SJF06081989P02.php)). Gail H. Mickey is identified as his wife in family obituaries ([Dignity Memorial](https://www.dignitymemorial.com/obituaries/richmond-va/hilda-hindman-6225649)). They have not appeared in recent county farmland program records or land-use advocacy efforts.
neighbors.influence_justification: Retired school official; honored by county

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage the Mickeys through a neighborly introduction, acknowledging Donald's service to the county schools. Emphasize transparency about the project timeline and assurances regarding maintenance of local roadways and scenery.

neighbors.name: Henry B. Davenport III & Faye B. Davenport
neighbors.claims: Henry B. Davenport III is the owner of 'Altona', a historic farm listed on the National Register of Historic Places ([Jefferson County HLC](http://jeffersoncountyhlc.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/Altona-Nomination-Packet.pdf)). The Davenport family has a long history in the county; Henry B. Davenport III successfully sued the Jefferson County Planning Commission in 1980 to secure approval for a residential subdivision on his property ([Justia](https://law.justia.com/cases/west-virginia/supreme-court/1980/14199-3.html)). The family has established the Imogene Coleman Davenport Riely Memorial Scholarship at Shepherd University ([Shepherd University Foundation](https://shepherduniversityfoundation.org/search-named-funds/?cpage=20)).
neighbors.influence_justification: Historic landowner; legal history with planning

approach_recommendations.engage: Highlight respect for the Davenport family’s generations in the area. Acknowledge their historic property 'Altona' and their past defense of property rights.

neighbors.name: Douglas B. Lutman
neighbors.claims: Douglas B. Lutman is associated with Lutman Properties LLC, a family business established in 2011 with a stated purpose of crop farming ([WV Secretary of State](https://apps.sos.wv.gov/business/corporations/organization.aspx?org=303635)). The entity has also engaged in residential development, receiving a Consent Order from the WV DEP in 2018 regarding land disturbance for a subdivision near Mannings ([WV DEP](https://dep.wv.gov/pio/Documents/Lutman%20Properties%2C%20LLC%20Signed%20Order%208741.pdf)). The Lutman family has ties to local governance; a Charles Lutman served on the Jefferson County Planning Commission in the early 1990s ([Justia](https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/appellate-courts/F3/2/48/615844/)).
neighbors.influence_justification: Developer; planning board ties

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage Douglas Lutman via shared agricultural and development interests. Note the family's history with both farming and subdivision development.

neighbors.name: Gary L. Irving Sr. and Dolores K. Irving
neighbors.claims: Gary L. Irving Sr. and Dolores K. Irving are recorded as landowners in Jefferson County, specifically associated with a parcel in the Bolivar area ([source](https://data.wvgis.wvu.edu/pub/RA/State/BL/Other/House_Tenure/Owner_Tenure_Jefferson.xlsx)). Gary L. Irving Sr. was listed individually in 2016 county tax records for the Bolivar Corporation district ([source](https://wvlegals.com/jefferson-county-wv-delinquent-tax-list-2016/)). A Gary L. Irving was recognized with a Wall Street Journal Award at Shepherd College (now Shepherd University) in Shepherdstown in 1970, suggesting potential long-standing educational ties to the local community ([source](https://archive.org/stream/picket1969-1974shepu/picket1969-1974shepU_djvu.txt)). No public profile of civic engagement, board membership, or stance on development was found for either individual.
neighbors.influence_justification: No public office or civic role

approach_recommendations.engage: As private individuals with potential long-term local ties, a personal, low-key approach through a mutual neighbor or community contact is recommended to build trust and share information discreetly.

neighbors.name: Turner B Guilford & Linda S-Tr
neighbors.claims: The property is held in trust by B. Guilford Turner and Linda S. Turner. B. Guilford Turner (Rev. B. Guilford Turner) was a local pastor who officiated numerous services in Jefferson County before his passing [Spirit of Jefferson](https://sjf.stparchive.com/Archive/SJF/SJF05061999P02.php). Linda S. Turner is a licensed real estate broker in West Virginia with Coldwell Banker Stuart and Watts, holding certifications in green building (GREEN) and internet professionalism (ePRO) [Coldwell Banker Agent Profile](https://www.coldwellbanker.com/wv/lewisburg/agents/linda-turner/aid-P00200000FDdtRrOb7CZMGig16uRFFCRUr9KLqMi). The trust structure indicates estate planning for the family assets. Linda Turner's professional background in real estate suggests a high level of sophistication regarding land value and property rights.
neighbors.influence_justification: Linda Turner is a real estate professional with local market knowledge; family has long-standing ties to the community (pastoral history).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage Linda Turner as a real estate professional; be prepared for detailed questions regarding property value impacts. Her 'GREEN' certification may indicate openness to renewable energy if presented as value-additive.

neighbors.claims: This parcel is owned by the Charles Town Seventh-day Adventist Church, located on Summit Point Road in Jefferson County, WV ([Adventist Directory](https://www.adventistdirectory.org/viewEntity.aspx?EntityID=15524)). The congregation has been active in the area for decades, with records of services and events dating back to the 1980s ([Spirit of Jefferson](https://sjf.stparchive.com/Archive/SJF/SJF12241998P18.php)).

neighbors.name: Dr Acquisitions Llc
neighbors.claims: DR Acquisitions LLC is a West Virginia limited liability company formed on July 29, 2004, with a stated purpose of residential building construction [WV Secretary of State](https://apps.sos.wv.gov/business/corporations/organization.aspx?org=228584). State filings list Dan Ryan of Frederick, Maryland, as the sole managing member, linking the entity to the DRB Group (formerly Dan Ryan Builders), a major regional homebuilder [WV Secretary of State](https://apps.sos.wv.gov/business/corporations/organization.aspx?org=228584). As of late 2025 and early 2026, the entity is actively seeking planning commission approval for Phase 4 of the 'Huntfield' neighborhood, a large mixed-use residential development in Charles Town [WV Legals](https://wvlegals.com/public-hearing-152/). The company has also requested amendments for recreational facilities within the Huntfield development, indicating ongoing active management of their land holdings [Spirit of Jefferson Legal Ads](https://wvlegals.com/legal-ads-feb-13-2025-spirit-of-jefferson/). The entity's property interests are strictly tied to residential expansion and development [Charles Town Planning Commission](https://d3n9y02raazwpg.cloudfront.net/charlestownwv/3a933cec-86e6-11ed-9024-0050569183fa-c3406839-89eb-44b9-8ad4-c6ca2b8d008b-1692890298.pdf).
neighbors.influence_justification: Major regional developer actively expanding the 'Huntfield' subdivision; regularly appears before Planning Commission; significant economic stakeholder in local housing market.

motivations: Visual aesthetics for future home sales
approach_recommendations.engage: Engage principal Dan Ryan or legal representatives regarding the Huntfield expansion; ensure project buffers align with their residential site plans to prevent opposition based on visual impact to their future home sales.

neighbors.profile_summary: Holding company for DRB Group (Dan Ryan Builders), currently active in permitting Phase 4 of the Huntfield subdivision.

citations.claim: Formed on July 29, 2004, with a stated purpose of residential building construction

neighbors.name: Winchester Cold Storage Co Inc
neighbors.claims: Winchester Cold Storage Company, Inc. is a Virginia-based cold logistics and orchard company registered in West Virginia since 2002 [WV Secretary of State](https://apps.sos.wv.gov/business/corporations/organization.aspx?org=206926). The company is led by President John Scully IV and Vice-President Harry F. Byrd III, representing prominent regional families involved in real estate and agriculture [WV Secretary of State](https://apps.sos.wv.gov/business/corporations/organization.aspx?org=206926). In June 2023, the Jefferson County Historic Landmarks Commission voted unanimously to designate the Winchester Cold Storage Building as a Jefferson County Historic Landmark, citing its significance to the regional apple industry [JCHLC Minutes June 2023](http://jeffersoncountyhlc.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/JCHLC-Minutes-June-7-2023.pdf). The facility, located west of Charles Town, has been operational since the mid-20th century and remains a functional part of the agricultural supply chain [JCHLC Nomination Report](http://jeffersoncountyhlc.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/Nomination-report-Winchester-Cold-Storage-Building-.pdf). John Scully IV is also a prominent realtor and former Winchester City Council member, indicating high community connectivity [Colony Realty Agent Profile](https://colonysells.com/agents/john-s-scully-iv/).
neighbors.influence_justification: Property is a designated Historic Landmark (2023); leadership includes the Byrd family (political dynasty) and John Scully IV (prominent realtor/civic leader).

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach with extreme care regarding visual impacts; acknowledge the 2023 Historic Landmark designation immediately. Frame the project as compatible with the working agricultural history of the site rather than industrial intrusion.

neighbors.profile_summary: Historic agricultural logistics company owned by influential Byrd and Scully families; property is a designated County Historic Landmark.

citations.claim: Registered in West Virginia since 2002
citations.title: WV Secretary of State - WINCHESTER COLD STORAGE COMPANY

citations.claim: Led by President John Scully IV and Vice-President Harry F. Byrd III

neighbors.name: Tuscawilla Hills Citizens Association Inc
neighbors.claims: Tuscawilla Hills Citizens Association Inc is the homeowners’ association for the Tuscawilla Hills subdivision, incorporated in West Virginia on January 30, 1976 [WV Secretary of State](https://apps.sos.wv.gov/business/corporations/organization.aspx?org=29509). The community consists of single-family homes built primarily in the 1970s, with amenities including a basketball court and common grounds [Zillow Property Details](https://www.zillow.com/homedetails/51-Packett-Dr-Charles-Town-WV-25414/22562023_zpid/). The HOA has been listed in tax lien notices in the past, specifically regarding a 'Notice to Redeem' in 2019 for delinquent taxes on a lot within the subdivision [Spirit of Jefferson](https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/spiritofjefferson.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/0/4d/04d5c020-709c-11eb-8ea6-db5cbbaf5b54/602c35eebe254.pdf.pdf). The association is professionally managed, with recent filings listing Clagett Management in Martinsburg as the point of contact [WV Secretary of State](https://apps.sos.wv.gov/business/corporations/organization.aspx?org=132879).
neighbors.influence_justification: Represents a significant residential block (~500 units); professionally managed; history of tax administrative issues suggests potential disorganization or financial constraints.

approach_recommendations.engage: Contact Clagett Management to reach the board; be aware of potential financial sensitivities given the tax lien history. Focus on how the project will not burden their common resources.

neighbors.profile_summary: HOA for Tuscawilla Hills subdivision; professionally managed but has history of tax liens on common parcels.

neighbors.name: Locust Hill Unitowner'S Association Inc
neighbors.claims: Locust Hill Unitowner’s Association Inc is the homeowners’ association for the Locust Hill golf-course community, incorporated in West Virginia on October 22, 1990 [WV Secretary of State](https://apps.sos.wv.gov/business/corporations/organization.aspx?org=132879). The community is professionally managed by Clagett Management Services in Martinsburg [WV Secretary of State](https://apps.sos.wv.gov/business/corporations/organization.aspx?org=132879). The HOA is highly active in enforcing community standards, evidenced by a 2024-2025 legal battle (Wilber v. Locust Hill Unit Owner's Association, Inc.) regarding a resident's display of a flag, which resulted in a jury verdict favoring the Association [Justia Law](https://law.justia.com/cases/west-virginia/intermediate-court-of-appeals/2025/24-ica-270.html). The association also maintains active vigilance over the property, recently issuing alerts regarding trespassers in the wooded areas [Locust Hill Community Blog](https://locusthillvt.org/author/locusthillcondo/).
neighbors.influence_justification: Large, organized community willing to litigate to enforce standards; highly vigilant regarding property boundaries and aesthetics.

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage via Clagett Management; expect strict scrutiny of any visual impacts or boundary encroachments. The HOA has demonstrated willingness to go to court over aesthetic/covenant disputes.

neighbors.profile_summary: Active and litigious HOA for a golf course community; recently won a court case regarding covenant enforcement.

overview_summary: Screening of 26 neighbors—comprising 21 residents and 5 organizations—reveals that all currently hold an unknown stance regarding the project. The profile includes 4 high-influence and 6 medium-influence entities, notably a regional homebuilder, a historic nonprofit estate, and two large homeowner associations representing approximately 1,000 households. Potential risks center on community mobilization regarding water resources and rural character preservation, particularly among established agricultural interests and mission-driven community groups.
